verses.text: Many have sinned for the sake of gain, and whoever seeks to multiply wealth turns his eye away.
verses.comment: This verse warns against greed and the temptation to sin for material gain. The idea that the pursuit of riches leads many astray is echoed in the New Testament (cf. 1 Tim. 6:9-10), further showing the continuity of wisdom throughout Scripture.
verses.sectionHeader: Warnings Against Sin in Trade and Speech

verses.text: Just as a stake is driven firmly between fitted stones, so sin wedges itself between selling and buying.
verses.comment: Here the text highlights how easily sin can enter ordinary business affairs. The image of a stake shows how subtle but powerful sin’s grip can be.

verses.text: If a man is not firmly resolved in the fear of the Lord, his house will quickly be overthrown.
verses.comment: True stability comes only from reverent awe of the Lord. Jesus’ teaching about building your house on the rock (Matt 7:24-27) echoes this Old Testament wisdom.

verses.text: When a sieve is shaken, the refuse remains; so the faults of a man appear when he speaks.
verses.comment: Just as a sieve separates waste, words reveal one’s heart. This anticipates Jesus’ own words about speech flowing from the heart’s abundance.

verses.text: The kiln tests the potter’s vessels; so a man is tried by the discussion of his thoughts.
verses.comment: Testing—whether by fire or words—reveals true character. This theme of trial leading to purity runs through both Testaments.

verses.text: The fruit declares if the tree has been well cultivated; so a word reveals the feelings of a man’s heart.
verses.comment: This wisdom that ‘by their fruits you will know them’ is made explicit by Jesus, showing the deep unity between wisdom literature and His teaching.

verses.text: Do not praise anyone before he speaks, for this is how the worth of a man is tested.
verses.comment: One’s character is revealed through words and actions, not appearances. Scripture always urges discernment before offering judgment.

verses.text: If you pursue righteousness, you will obtain it, and put it on like a splendid robe.
verses.comment: Pursuing holiness is portrayed as being clothed in righteousness—a significant biblical image continued in the teachings of the apostles about putting on Christ.
verses.sectionHeader: The Rewards of Righteousness and the Company of Fools

verses.text: Birds gather with their own kind, and truth returns to those who practice it.
verses.comment: The proverb reflects the biblical principle of community and the importance of living according to truth, leading to authentic unity among believers.

verses.text: A lion lies in wait for its prey; so does sin for those who do wrong.
verses.comment: Sin is described as an active predator—an idea later echoed regarding the devil ‘prowling like a roaring lion’ (1 Pet. 5:8).

verses.text: The words of the godly will always be wise, but the fool changes like the moon.
verses.comment: Those who know the Lord speak with constancy and wisdom, pointing to the fruit of a life rooted in God’s Word.

verses.text: When among the foolish, take care to observe the times; but linger with those who understand the Lord.
verses.comment: Here is both a warning and encouragement regarding one’s company. Fellowship with the wise deepens knowledge of the Lord—a principle foundational to Christian community.

verses.text: The conversation of fools is offensive, their laughter is sinful, and their boasting is sinful pride.
verses.comment: This verse stresses moral caution in speech and company. A Christian life seeks humility and purity in conversation.

verses.text: Cursing and quarreling bring one to continual strife; the ears will listen only to angry disputes.
verses.comment: Unrestrained speech leads to conflict. James later teaches the need to be slow to speak and quick to listen.

verses.text: The quarrels of the proud end in bloodshed, and their insults are grievous to hear.
verses.comment: Pride and harsh words lead to destruction—a warning picked up by Jesus, who equates anger and insult with breaking God’s law.

verses.text: Whoever betrays secrets destroys trust, and can never find a true friend.
verses.comment: Faithfulness is central to friendship. Scriptural teaching on loyalty and discretion foreshadows the profound call to integrity among believers.

verses.text: Love your neighbor and keep to your agreements; but if you reveal secrets, you chase away friends.
verses.comment: The biblical command to love one’s neighbor is here joined with the importance of trust in relationship—a theme foundational for the New Testament vision of the Church.

verses.text: As you let a bird escape from your hand, so you let your neighbor go and will not get him back.
verses.comment: Once trust is broken, restoring it is almost impossible. This illustrates the gravity with which Scripture treats relationships.

verses.text: As you let a bird escape from your hand, so you have let your neighbor go, and will not catch him again.
verses.comment: This verse uses the image of a released bird to illustrate the finality of losing trust or a close relationship—once broken, some relationships, especially those involving betrayal, cannot be restored (cf. Proverbs 25:9-10).

verses.text: Do not go after him, for he is too far off, and has escaped like a gazelle from a snare.
verses.comment: Sirach warns not to pursue a friend who has distanced themselves after betrayal, expressing an ancient awareness that some losses, like a swift gazelle escaping a snare, are irretrievable (see Proverbs 6:5).

verses.text: For a wound may be bandaged, and there is reconciliation after abuse, but whoever has betrayed secrets is without hope.
verses.comment: While physical wounds and certain offenses may be healed or forgiven, the betrayal of confidential secrets is depicted as an especially grievous sin, often destroying any hope of reconciliation (cf. Proverbs 11:13; 16:28).

verses.text: Whoever winks the eye plots mischief, and those who know him will keep their distance.
verses.comment: The 'wink' is a biblical symbol of deceitfulness or secret plotting (see Proverbs 6:13; 10:10), suggesting that those known for cunning behavior eventually become isolated by the wise.

verses.text: In your presence his mouth is all sweetness, and he admires your words; but later he will twist his speech and with your own words he will trip you up.
verses.comment: This verse highlights hypocrisy: a person may use flattering speech in one's presence but later twists those words to cause harm, paralleling warnings in Psalm 55:21 and James 3:9-10 about duplicitous speech.

verses.text: I have hated many things, but him above all; even the Lord hates him.
verses.comment: Sirach expresses strong moral revulsion—echoed as divine hatred—toward the treacherous deceiver, underscoring the severity with which God views malicious duplicity (cf. Proverbs 6:16-19).

verses.text: Whoever throws a stone straight up throws it on his own head, and a treacherous blow opens up many wounds.
verses.comment: The proverb warns that treachery backfires: a person who schemes harm ultimately injures themselves, aligning with biblical principles of retribution (cf. Psalm 7:15-16; Proverbs 26:27).

verses.text: A stone thrown straight up will strike the thrower; a treacherous blow will wound the one who deals it.
verses.comment: The principle of reaping what one sows is a universal moral law grounded in both wisdom and New Testament teaching (Gal. 6:7).

verses.text: If a person does evil, it will roll back upon him, and he will not know where it came from.
verses.comment: Plots against others often backfire. This wisdom is referenced often in the Psalms and elsewhere (see also Prov. 26:27).

verses.text: Mockery and abuse issue from the proud, but vengeance lies in wait for them like a lion.
verses.comment: Evil returns upon the evildoer—a foundation for divine justice, fully realized in Christ’s victory over evil.

verses.text: Those who rejoice in the fall of the godly will be caught in a snare, and pain will consume them before their death.
verses.comment: Pride precedes destruction. The lion imagery points again to the peril of spiritual pride, which is consistently condemned throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Anger and wrath, these also are abominations, yet a sinner holds on to them.
verses.comment: This conclusion points to the destructive power of unforgiveness and anger. Forgiveness is a core teaching of Christ and marks the truly spiritual person; holding on to wrath impedes full restoration within the Church.
